I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Republic of the Union of Myanmar for the Greater Mekong Subregion Highway Modernization 
Project. 
 
2. 
The project will improve transport conditions on Myanmar’s East–West Economic Corridor 
(EWEC) and North–South Economic Corridor (NSEC) by (i) improving about 99 kilometers (km) 
of Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) highways, (ii) improving the safety of the Yangon–Mandalay 
expressway, and (iii) preparing detailed designs for other highway projects on the GMS corridors. 
The  project  expands  efforts  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  other  development 
partners  to  upgrade  the  country’s  national  highway  network  along  the  GMS  corridors.  It  will 
promote inclusive economic growth in Myanmar and regional cooperation and integration. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Strategic context. Myanmar remains one of the poorest countries in Southeast Asia, with 
an estimated per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of $1,264 (2017). To increase economic 
growth and reduce poverty, Myanmar’s transport system needs to be modernized. In particular, 
the GMS road corridors are the backbone of Myanmar’s transport system. However, the quality 
of  the  infrastructure  along  the  GMS  corridors  is  weak  and  lacks  connectivity—fourteen  million 
people do not have basic road access in Myanmar. Improving the capacity, safety, and condition 
of the GMS corridors will reduce national transport costs, facilitate access to Myanmar’s remote 
ethnic minority areas, and improve regional connectivity, lifting many out of poverty. 
 
4. 
The NSEC, which links Yangon with Mandalay and the People’s Republic of China, is the 
essential trading route of the country. The EWEC connects Thailand with Yangon and its Thilawa 
Special  Economic  Zone  and  then  onward  to  Pathein,  the  capital  of  the  Ayeyarwaddy  Region, 
which is one of the poorest regions in Myanmar and most vulnerable to disasters and the impacts 
of climate change. The improvement of the EWEC will also facilitate access to Mon and Kayin 
states,  which  will  spur  economic  activity  and  demonstrate  the  government’s  commitment  to 
improving the well-being of people in areas that have long been affected by conflict.1 To spread 
the  benefits  of  trunk  highway  improvements  to  local  communities,  ADB  has  been  helping  the 
government set up a national rural road strategy,2 and is preparing the proposed Rural Roads 
and Access Project, planned for 2019 approval. ADB estimates that GDP per capita could reach 
$3,500 by 2030, if the Government of Myanmar implements necessary market policies and large 
infrastructure investments, particularly those aimed at improving Myanmar’s highway network.3
 
 
Need to modernize highway network. Demand for road transport has increased quickly 
5. 
since  2012,  when  the  government  eased  vehicle  import  restrictions.  During  2012–2016,  the 
number of cars registered in Myanmar increased by 80%, the number of motorcycles increased 
by 145%, and the number of trucks increased by 280%. The sudden increase in road traffic has 
worsened pavement conditions, caused congestion (particularly around Yangon and on the main

 international corridors), and increased road crashes and fatalities. There were about 5,000 road-
related fatalities in 2016, up from 2,173 in 2009.4 
 
6. 
However, the condition of Myanmar’s basic transport infrastructure is poor due to years of 
inadequate  investment  and  lack  of  access  to  modern  technology.  Only  53%  of  the  40,000  km 
trunk  road  network  managed  by  the  Department  of  Highways  (DOH)  was  paved  as  of  2015. 
Pavement  works  were  done  using  outdated,  labor-intensive  methods.  Insufficient  design  and 
quality control have produced rough surfaces that are vulnerable to intense rain events and need 
frequent maintenance. The main roads are vulnerable to climate events (e.g., typhoons, storm 
surges, and floods), which are expected to become more frequent and intense in the future. 
 
7. 
Highway improvement priorities. With ADB support, the Ministry of Construction (MOC) 
completed  condition  surveys  (2015)  on  27,000  km  of  national  roads,  designed  an  asset 
management  strategy,  and  identified  about  5,000  km  of  priority  roads.  The  MOC  developed  a 
road  masterplan5  in  2016,  which  prioritized  the  project  highways  for  rehabilitation  and 
improvement based on strategic alignment with government priorities and the GMS corridors, as 
well as the economic viability of the proposed works.  
 
8. 
Expressway  safety  program.  ADB  completed  in  2016  a  strategic  review,  which 
recommended that the government develop a road safety investment program, improve the safety 
of the Yangon–Mandalay expressway, and consider opening it to truck traffic to reduce logistics 
costs (footnote 4). Road crashes on this expressway killed 280 people during 2014–2015, and 
trucks are banned from using it because the government believes it would be too hazardous. In 
2016,  the  MOC  created  a  road  safety  unit  and  began  safety  improvement  works  on  the 
expressway. With ADB’s assistance, it developed an expressway safety improvement program 
for which it requested ADB financing. 
 
9. 
Grade-separated  highway  development.  To  address  long-term  highway  capacity 
needs,  the  MOC’s  2016  master  plan  also  considered  the  development  of  a  grade-separated 
expressway network (footnote 5). Eventually, new road alignments will be needed to improve the 
EWEC,  particularly  on  the  Bago–Kyaikto  section.  Upgrading  the  current  alignment  is  not  the 
preferred  solution  because  it  is  too  long  and  winding.  Myanmar  has  limited  experience  with 
modern engineering design for grade-separated highways and requires international assistance 
to  develop  the  new  highway  project.  The  project  will  be  prepared  in  partnership  with  Japan 
International Cooperation Agency. ADB is preparing the project feasibility study under a technical 
assistance project.6 Once the feasibility study is completed, the project will finance the preparation 
of  the  detailed  design.  Financing  for  the  construction  of  the  new  highway  will  be  processed 
separately  through  the  proposed  Second  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Highway  Modernization 
Project, formerly the GMS EWEC Highway Development Project, planned for 2020 approval. In 
parallel, Japan International Cooperation Agency is considering financing the construction of a 
bridge on the Sittaung River, which is part of the new alignment. 
 
10. 
Value  added  by  ADB  assistance.  Since  2012,  transport  has  been  a  pillar  of  ADB’s 
reengagement  strategy  in  Myanmar.  ADB’s  strategy  focuses  on  improving  access  and 
connectivity to connect rural and urban areas and markets, and to link Myanmar with the regional

The  project  is  included  in  ADB’s  country  operations  business  plan,  2017–2019  for

trunk roads.

Impact and Outcome 

B. 
 
12. 
The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  all-weather  and  safe  road  transport 
infrastructure developed.13 The project will have the following outcome: efficiency and safety of 
road traffic along the GMS EWEC and NSEC in Myanmar improved.14 
 
C. 
 
Output 1: Greater Mekong Subregion highways improved. The project will upgrade at 
13. 
least 99 km of highway along GMS corridors, primarily the Bago–Thanlyin highway section of the 
EWEC, under this output. The road works will provide a pavement width and an asphalt concrete 
pavement  designed  to  meet  future  traffic  growth.  Bridges  that  are  in  poor  condition  or  below 
standard will be replaced. Some highway sections are vulnerable to flooding and quick pavement 
deterioration after extreme rain events. To address climate risks, several adaptation measures—
increased embankment height, improved pavement surfacing, improved bridges and drains—are 
included in the project design. 
 
14. 
Output 2: Safety of Yangon–Mandalay expressway improved. The project will improve 
the  safety  of  the  Yangon–Mandalay  expressway.  The  65  km  section  from  Hlegu  in  Yangon  to 
Bawnetgyi near Bago, which is common to the EWEC and the NSEC, will be improved to enable 
future use by trucks. Following the improvements, a community-based road safety program will 
be carried out to improve the behavior of road users. On the rest of the expressway (about 530 
km), the project will mitigate the most serious safety risks attributable to engineering by providing 
signage and line marking and installing safety barriers at some critical bridge approaches. The 
project will identify areas prone to frequent crashes and, when feasible, make them safer. 
 
15. 
Output  3:  Detailed  design  for  other  highway  projects  prepared.  The  project  will 
finance  consulting  services  to  carry  out  detailed  engineering  design,  safeguard  planning, 
procurement support, and other studies needed to prepare technically and economically viable 
highway  projects.  This  will  include  preparation  for  the  improvement  of  the  Yangon–Pathein 
highway (165 km) and the development of a new highway alignment from Bago to Kyaikto (about 
70 km). ADB has advised the borrower that approval of the financing for the detailed design does 
not commit ADB to finance a subsequent project. 
 
D. 
 
The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $202.1  million  (Table  2).  Detailed  cost  estimates  by 
16. 
expenditure category and by financier are included in the project administration manual (PAM).15 
To  finance  the  program,  the  government  has  requested  a  concessional  loan  of  $194.7  million 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources. The loan will have a 32-year term, including a grace period 
of 8 years; an interest rate of 1.0% per year during the grace period and 1.5% per year thereafter; 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
The  technical  due  diligence  undertaken  during  project  preparation  confirmed  that  the 
20. 
project’s technical designs are appropriate for roads in these locations—in terms of alignment, 
cross-sections, structural characteristics, and road safety provisions—and for the projected traffic 
volume. Pavement structures have been selected to enable a 15-year design life. The underlying 
traffic  projection  is  based  on  present  traffic  volumes,  with  growth  rates  that  consider  the  likely 
rapid increase in traffic that will occur as Myanmar’s economy continues to develop. 
 
21. 
The Yangon–Mandalay expressway safety improvement output of the project will reduce 
road safety risks and enable a pilot section to be used by trucks. The works involve paving the 
inner and outer shoulders of the expressway and overlaying the existing rough cement concrete 
pavement with asphalt concrete. The expressway’s median will be reshaped, and a rope barrier 
will  be  added.  Surveys  carried  out  during  project  preparation  confirmed  that  the  current 
expressway’s concrete pavement had sufficient strength to be used by trucks, except for a few 
weak slabs that will be replaced under the project. 
 
B. 
 
22. 
Economic viability. The project is economically viable. The main benefits of the highway 
improvement works under output 1 are reduced vehicle operating costs and shorter travel times. 
Compared  with  the  without-project  situation,  highway  widening  will  limit  congestion,  thereby 
reducing travel time. The expressway improvement and safety works will reduce logistics costs 
and decrease the frequency and social cost of road crashes. The overall economic internal rate 
of return of the project is 13.1%.  

Economic and Financial 

 

 7 

Governance 

 
23. 
Financial viability. The sustainability of the project highways depends on general budget 
appropriations  for  road  maintenance.  In  2016,  the  Government  of  Myanmar  and  state 
governments allocated about $250 million for trunk road maintenance through the DOH. This level 
is  considered  adequate  given  the  size  of  the  network.  Moreover,  to  ensure  long-term  budget 
adequacy, the government plans to set up a road user tax on fuel and earmark this revenue for 
supporting road investments and maintenance, possibly through a road fund. 
 
C. 
 
24. 
Institutional  capacity.  The  DOH  has  gained  experience  in  implementing  two  ADB-
financed  projects  (footnote  7).  The  PMU  is  headed  by  a  project  director  with  the  rank  of  chief 
engineer. In  parallel  to  the  project,  ADB  will  strengthen the  PMU’s  capacity  in  safeguards  and 
financial management through technical assistance. 
 
25. 
Financial  management.  The  pre-mitigation  financial  management  risk  is  substantial 
mainly because of weaknesses in government-wide financial management systems. The DOH 
will set up a PMU to manage day-to-day activities, including project-specific financial management 
tasks to mitigate the risks. As the DOH is already implementing two other ADB-financed projects, 
it  has  knowledge  and  experience  regarding  ADB  policies  and  procedures  (para.  10).  ADB’s 
Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the 
government. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the 
PAM (footnote 15). 
 
D. 
 
26. 
Poverty. The main beneficiaries of the project will be residents of rural areas of Bago and 
Yangon regions, users of the Yangon–Mandalay expressway, and passengers and shippers using 
the GMS EWEC. The rural areas of Bago and Yangon regions are among the poorest areas in 
Myanmar  and  roads  there  are  particularly  vulnerable  to  climate  impacts  (e.g.,  floods  and 
typhoons). In 2014, 35% of residents of the Yangon Region and 25% of residents of the Bago 
Region  lived  in  poverty. 16  Poverty  in  rural  areas,  where  township-specific  data  do  not  exist,  is 
higher. The  Yangon–Mandalay  expressway  has  had  a  poor  safety  record  since  its  opening  in 
2011. This poor safety record has led the government to ban trucks from using the expressway. 
Trucks use the old Yangon–Mandalay parallel highway instead, which is congested and unsafe 
as it passes through many communities. There were 605 road-related fatalities on the old highway 
in 2015. The project will improve the safety of road users and pedestrians and provide stronger 
links between the rural and poor regions and the more developed urban hub of Yangon. 
 
27. 
Gender.  The  project  is  classified  some  gender  elements.  Gender-friendly  elements 
include (i) undertaking gender-sensitive community-based programs on road safety, HIV/AIDS, 
and human trafficking; (ii) ensuring that at least 50% of community facilitators in such programs 
are women; and (iii) ensuring that at least 50% of government staff that will be trained under the 
project will be women. 
 
28. 
HIV/AIDS  and  trafficking.  The  project  will  improve  existing  corridors  and  is  thus  not 
expected to significantly increase the incidence of HIV/AIDS, sexually transmitted infections, and 
human  trafficking.  However,  the  increased  presence  of  road  workers  during  construction  and

 increased traffic may elevate the risk of HIV/AIDS transmission. Disruption to livelihoods caused 
by the displacement of several shops along the project alignment may increase human trafficking 
risks as well. To mitigate these risks, the contractors will put in place prevention and assistance 
programs for their workers, and the project management and contract supervision consultant will 
oversee a community awareness program.17 
 
29. 
Conflict sensitivity. The project does not finance anything directly in any of the conflict-
affected  areas  in  Myanmar.  Within  the  Bago  and  Yangon  regions,  which  have  not  faced  any 
conflicts, the project will  benefit all ethnic groups in a fair, unbiased and equal manner. ADB’s 
ongoing  GMS  EWEC  Eindu  to  Kawkareik  Road  Improvement  Project  (Footnote  7)  supports 
directly  the  upgrading  of  a  66-km  section  of  the  GMS  EWEC  in  Kayin  state,  which  has  faced 
significant conflicts. While the proposed project does not have any components in Kayin state, it 
will contribute in important ways to conflict resolution in the state. The upgraded Bago–Thanlyin 
highway section under the project, and the new Bago–Kyaikto highway which will be designed 
under  the  project  and  considered  for  financing  under  the  proposed  Second  GMS  Highway 
Modernization  Project  (planned  2020  approval),  will  become  important  conduits  for  greater 
mobility of people between Kayin, the rest of Myanmar, and regionally. The sequence of projects 
will ultimately halve the travel times from Kayin state to Yangon and the associated logistics costs. 
The people of Kayin state could benefit from higher education and specialized health care choices 
available in the more developed regions of Myanmar. Further, by connecting the EWEC segments 
that are being upgraded in Kayin state with the rest of country and regionally, there will be greater 
trade opportunities for Kayin state, which in turn could foster growth, reduce poverty and facilitate 
conflict resolution. 
 
E.

31. 
Environment  (category  B).  The  project  is  not  expected  to  cause  significant  adverse 
environmental  impacts.  The  MOC  has  prepared  an  initial  environmental  examination  report 
following the requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and Myanmar’s environmental 
impact  assessment  procedure.  Public  consultation  was  undertaken,  and  a  grievance  redress 
mechanism  has  been  designed  to  address  issues  and  complaints  that  may  arise  during 
construction.  The  main  potential  adverse  environmental  impacts  are  on  (i)  air  quality,  water 
quality, and receptors sensitive to noise and dust; (ii) land use and soils; (iii) roadside trees; and 
(iv) worker and community health and safety. The cutting and removal of roadside trees to allow 
for road widening works and to promote road safety are expected to be a concern for communities 
and  local  governments.  Impacts  will  be  offset  through  replacement  planting  and  tree  aftercare 
programs developed by the MOC in consultation with Myanmar’s Forest Department.
